title: Wawelberg Bank building
text:
The Wawelberg Bank Building in <a href="St.%20Petersburg">St. Petersburg</a>, <a href="Russia">Russia</a> was built by the <a href="Wawelberg">Wawelberg</a>s - a prominent <a href="Poles">Polish</a> banking <a href="family">family</a> active in the <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russian Empire</a>. Although this <a href="building">building</a> bears initials "HW" (<a href="Hipolit%20Wawelberg">Hipolit Wawelberg</a>), it was commissioned by his son, <a href="Michael%20Wawelberg%23Michael%20Wawelberg">Michael Wawelberg</a>.
It is located at "7/9 Nevsky Prospekt" and is an important <a href="Nevsky%20Prospekt">Nevsky Prospekt</a> landmark.
Architect <a href="Marian%20Peretiatkovich">Marian Peretiatkovich</a>, also Peretyatkovich, Peretiatkowicz; 
Style: Historicism, Neo-Renaissance with elements of <a href="Art%20Nouveau">Art Nouveau</a>
History.
The present <a href="building">building</a> was completed in 1912 and incorporates the <a href="Foundation%20%28architecture%29">foundation</a> and some of the <a href="structure">structure</a> of two separate 18th century buildings. In the 18th century the property owners were two brothers, Semen (Semion) Bernikov and Sergei Bernikov, both wealthy merchants. In the early 19th century one T. Roby (Thomas Roby, Robbie, Т.Роби), a <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a> subject, ran a <a href="restaurant">restaurant</a> or <a href="pub">pub</a> in this <a href="building">building</a>. Around the 1850s Bernikov's heirs sold one building to Shchepetilova, an army captain's widow, and the second structure to some Nochbeck, a government official. New owners in turn later sold the structure to another pair of merchant brothers, Nikolai (Nicholas) and Karl Korpus (Charles Corpus) who remained landlords until they sold both properties to Wawelberg interests in the early 20th century. From the 1870s until 1910 the building housed a variety of retail establishments and agencies: Captain Mahlein's (капитан Малейн) footwear shop, Betling s governess employment bureau (контора для найма гувернанток и Елизаветы Карловны Бетлинг). Art studios (of <a href="August%20Rakowski">August Rakowski</a>, a painter) occupied the mansard space, Ivanov's fruit emporium, Schaf's or Schaff's (Шаф) weapons and bicycle shop were also in the building before Wawelberg's takeover.
Architecture.
The <a href="structure">structure</a> is a heavy Italianate <a href="palazzo">palazzo</a> built on gargantuan scale - it occupies a full city block. The exterior of the building is made of gray <a href="granite">granite</a>. Walls, <a href="cornice">cornice</a>s, columns are richly decorated with <a href="National%20Romantic%20style">northern art nouveau</a> inspired sculptures and bas-reliefs by two notable period sculptors <a href="Vasily%20Kozlov%20%28sculptor%29">Vasily Kozlov</a> (Vassili, Василий Васильевич Козлов) and <a href="Leopold%20Dietrich">Leopold Dietrich</a> (Леопольд Августович Дитрих). After 1917 Kozlov and Dietrich became official Soviet sculptors of the <a href="social%20realism">social realism</a> persuasion. Many contemporaries considered the building too American, too tasteless, and its appearance generated some heated public debate. At the corner of Malaia Morskaia and Nevsky is an entrance to the <a href="Retail%20banking">actual bank</a>, now housing a collection of travel agencies, from 1960 until 1992 the building was Leningrad headquarters of <a href="Aeroflot">Aeroflot</a>, the space is airy, quiet with entrance passage leading through a hall to the cavernous bank lobby, complete with rows of columns and a spacious gallery above. Wawelberg Bank is one of the most remarkable turn of the 20th century bank buildings in St. Petersburg. The exterior of the building bears HW - Hyppolite Wawelberg - initials set in an arrangement resembling a <a href="coat%20of%20arms">coat of arms</a>.
